reviewText:
The Path is the only game from developer, Tale of Tales, that I thoroughly enjoy. If I had to narrow it down as to why that is, it would be due to the extremely mature themes and musical dissonance, combined with the exploration of the forest. Each item you find is unique to the character you play and, upon discovery, your character will interact with the object and an image will be superimposed over the screen, as if it were a memory.

There are six characters in all, each with their own unique locations and encounters with the wolf. Once your encounter with the wolf has been made you are left on the path, in the pouring rain, heading for your grandmother's house one last time. Upon arrival your character experiences their final nightmare and you are returned to the home screen to choose the next playable character.

The music and sound design is what becomes most dissonant in The Path. The off-tune choir of girls singing, mixed with an assortment of synths playing to heavy chains clanking in the background. It's all very unsettling.

The Path focuses on very serious themes without directly implying what has happened. If you find the topics of ♥♥♥♥ and child abuse horrifying then I advise you not to play this game. Nothing explicit is shown, it is merely suggested. It is up to you to put the pieces together.

reviewText:
The Path is a walking simulator and adventure/horror game, where the horror mostly is implied.
You take on the role of one of six sisters, each representing a different stage of womanhood, from little girl who only wants to play to a grown-up woman with adult wants.
Each girl enters a path through the forest, at the other end of which is grandmother's house. Walk there, and the game for that girl ends.

Of course, that's not where the real gameplay is. Instead, go into the forest. A strange girl clad in white tries to guide you further away from the path, and strange white distortion on the edge of your screen guides your character to other spots. You can pick up flowers along the way (which do nothing but increase a counter -- really, you don't get a thing for picking them all up) and also find strange items. Some of these can be interacted with, many cannot as they are meant for another sister.
Each item you can interact with gets added to the basket.

Eventually you will find the Wolf. The Wolf takes on a form which is meaningful to the sister you're playing as, and leads her to her death. These deaths range from the obvious (little girl gets eaten) to  the vaguely implied (talent agent destroys her? Woodsman rapes her?) -- a lot of this is left to interpretation.

After each wolf encounter the girl is back on the path, but the only way to go is move forward -- slowly, limping -- to grandmother's house. If you picked up the right items along the way the house becomes a kind of horror slideshow with distorted graphics and sounds reminiscent of what you found in the forest...

It is a strange and unique game definitely worth playing. Just don't think you'll fully understand all of it.

Also of note is that the game's demo is actually a fully separate level"

reviewText:
Just a warning. This game is obviously not for everyone. I know Steam is in no way related to Ps3, but if you know “Journey” the game or have played it and liked it then this is a lot like that. A really relaxing game when you don’t want a challenge, but something to reflect on. This is more for people who like artsy games. Some people call it pretentious and that’s fine to have that opinion. I personally have poured hours into this after long days and like to discover the symbolism and weave my own story with the pieces I find. There is really a lot you can figure out or imagine if you are into characters and stories.
Basically this purely explorative. Just walk, run, look and observe. That’s all there is to it. Some people find this too basic, but I think there should be both complex and simple games out there. If you don’t like easy stories and easy games- then don’t get this. But if you’re like me and love a little exploration than this is for you. My only problem? The camera sometimes gets a little wonky when I’m observing. But it isn’t every time and it’s not like you’re going to be in one place for long. This game is otherwise beautiful!
The game will tell you to stay on the path. But here is the moral of the story; if you take the road where everything is paved out for you, then you don’t earn any experiences and you don’t learn anything about life. Everything is too safe and you will never know real life. Going off the path leads you to both good and bad experiences. The story is going for a bit of a darker theme and some people might think it’s too dark, but I think you can interpret it as something a little bit less so. I don’t really want to get into spoiler territory, but I’ll just say this; death in these types of games doesn’t always literally mean death, but death to a part of a character’s personality or how they look at life. The real objective is to find each of the girls their own “wolf” which symbolizes different things. These wolves are the main even that will change their lives for better or worse. You decide. There are plenty of people who have come up with awesome theories. And that’s part of the fun!

reviewText: The Path is an interesting, thought-provoking game that takes a lot of pleasure in making us wonder what a 'game' is and to which extent it can blend with other genres. Playing The Path is like reading a book: there is no voice-acting, you have to read the thoughts of the six main characters to understand who they are and the nature of their desires and fears. Sometimes, it is like playing a record: the eerie, yet beautiful soundtrack plays a decisive role in setting the atmosphere of the game. The Path is not a traditional horror game: it plays with the player's sensitivity. I personally had to close the game once because I was just afraid. Afraid of the paradox that the Path presents us: if we take the safe path and  go to grandmother's house unharmed, nothing happens (even though the grandmother is quite terrifying in my opinion, but this is not relevant here). To 'beat' the game, we have to encounter the wolf. Its form is always different, sometimes surprising. It completes and ends the girl's path, and helps us understand her better. I am currently replaying the game to better understand what happens and sharpen my interpretations.\n\nThe music, the graphics, plus the work on the shading, blended with the subtle characterization of Robin, Rose, Ginger, Ruby, Carmen and Scarlet, bring into being a wonderful game. One that moves deeply and definitely asks for your point of view to become whole.

reviewText:
I'm pretty open-minded when it comes to indie games, and I have a real fondness for less conventional games like Dear Esther and Gone Home. But The Path seriously pushed me to my limits of tolerance on this front. It's a game that is very obviously trying too hard, and lets its own mechanics get in the way of whatever point it's trying to make. Be warned, if you're going to give this one a chance at all, go play it yourself and come back because I'm going to spoil the hell out of it. I'm sure it's even less effective if you know what to expect.

You pick one of six girls fresh from Hot Topic to visit their grandmother in the woods. The game tells you up front to stay on the path, and here it commits possibly its greatest sin. My first time through I made the slow walk straight down the path to a surprisingly sinister house. Inside the pitch-black cottage the girl made her way to her corpse-like grandmother and laid down next to her. The game then informed me that I had found no items, unlocked no rooms, not encountered the wolf, and that I had failed.

So, to reiterate, the game told me to do a thing, I did the thing, and then it told me I failed.

YOU CAN'T DO THAT YOU ♥♥♥♥S. If subversion of authority is a theme of your game then you need to introduce it in some way within the body of the game! I'm not going to read your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed treatise on your store page to figure out how to play your game. Fine, whatever, I picked another girl and walked straight off the path. The lighting and sound get creepy until you run across some random point of interest in the woods, like a theater stage or sofa or TV or pond. There are items to collect like knives and two-headed teddy bears. I met a little ballerina girl who spouted some nonsense about chaos and led me back to the path. After a whole bunch of exploring I went back to grandma's house. I got treated to a slightly different path through the rooms and then another screen that said I failed.

At this point I gave up trying to figure out what the game wants. Wandering the woods is interesting for a bit, but hamstrung by the glacial speed at which you move and the horrible sketchy-artsy filters the game vomits all over your view. There's really no common theme or identifiable symbolism to the junk you find, either. It's just weird for the sake of being weird. Or maybe it isn't... the store page says the optimal experience is to play for 6 hours. There are something like 13 items to collect and another 144 flowers you can pick, but I doubt very much I'm going to divine The Path's true meaning if I keep at it.

Appropriating the creepy side of Red Riding Hood isn't a bad idea for a game, but this one gets so caught up in trying to be clever and poignant that it all falls completely flat. Maybe there's something to find in here, but it's too damn boring and obtuse to get at it.

reviewText:
If you're looking for action and adventure, don't buy this game. If you're looking for jumpscares, don't buy this game. But if you're looking for subtle tension, thoughtful and ambiguous themes, implied and frankly somewhat disturbing horror, and beautiful art, buy this game. It's an atmospheric game, and the developers create the atmosphere perfectly. Oh and if you're afraid of thinking, this game isn't for you.

You begin in an apartment where you can pick one of six sisters. Each sister has different items you can interact with in the forest/a different wolf (not a literal wolf except in the case of the youngest sister, Robin). Each encounter could be interpreted many different ways. Personally I think that it's a loss of innocence story. Each girl meets something that they must face as they move into adulthood. The wolf is the most important part of the story. Once you reach the end of a girl's story, you will be told success" or "failure" based upon whether or not you met the wolf (meeting the wolf=success). You also get a rating based upon how many of the girl's individual items/secret rooms you found.

I've played for an hour and that's enough time to meet the wolf with two girls and collect about half of their items. However
date:
you can spend hours in this game if you have enough patience. There are tons of different disturbing endings you can get based on which items you collect.

Do note that the game is not "complete" until you've found the wolf which each sister (by leaving the path) and then walk the path with the girl who presumably represents childhood innocence. Then the game restarts and you can try again with a girl you've already found a wolf with.

Overall it's not a fun game. It's a thinking and patience game that tells its story with beautiful art and excellent atmosphere. It's a great work and easily worth $10."

reviewText:
First, this game has its merits.  It has great atmosphere and the graphics aren't bad and the gameplay itself is creative and thought-provoking.  But straight up, if you don't like games that have an inconsistent story that gives you no answers, The Path isn't for you.  If you like games that make you think...The Path probably still isn't for you.

Tale of Tales as a developer has completely imploded their own fanbase with their behavior lately, yes, and it's really made me reconsider this game.  Originally I thought a lot of thought went into this game; the developers established Livejournal accounts for the characters, there are a lot of details in the game, the girls all have some sort of personality and it seems like there's a mysterious story unfolding behind all this.

It sure SEEMS that way.

But the thing is, if you set up a mystery that no one else can solve and then insist that they don't get it" because it's ABOUT not solving the mystery
date: but about "appreciating" the "puzzle as it was left unsolved
recommended:
then that sort of makes you sound deep and mysterious yourself.  It sort of shifts the focus from the creation and onto the creator, the only person who has any answers about the otherwise completely unintelligible piece of work.  And frankly, after their freakout, Tale of Tales definitely sounds like a duo way more interested in shifting attention onto themselves.

And I was really committed to putting together the puzzle of The Path once.  I pulled apart the girls' Livejournals and was really baffled that their situation seemed to indicate that The Path was an experience they had...all the time?  Regularly?  And that their mother insisted they only go on the path itself by themselves??  It started to seem like the developers were not interested in creating some macabre version of hell or surreal depiction of time, but had set up characters they could pretty much do whatever they pleased with, as long as that gave them attention.

Honestly, if you set up a game to seem all deep and mysterious with individual sad stories to piece together, but then roleplay your characters as just whatever, it sorrrrta seems like you actually got nothing to say.

I didn't want to believe this was the case before, but after seeing their attitude about the failure of their game Sunset, their interest in only having a small (elite) fanbase, and their total disregard for making their games accessible to people, I just don't think the people behind Tale of Tales possess the sympathy and depth to create a game that demonstrates sympathy and depth.

It was a huge disappointment.

The Path is not deep.  The Path does not have secret answers or an underlying meaning.  The Path is just a very creative atmosphere, all dressed up with nowhere to go.  If you get something out of it, it'll be inspiration for some better story.

reviewText:
It’s a few years since I first came across The Path, by Tale of Tales but, on re-entering the fictional world of the sisters, I find the game has lost none of its appeal.  Originally released in 2009 and loosely based around Red Riding Hood, The Path was intended as a different kind of video game with an emphasis on partaking in a narrative, rather than being structured around quests and conquests.  However, I feel there is an element of strategy involved as the player is graded according to how many objects they find, how many of the secret rooms they unlock in Grandma’s house.

Game play is deceptively simple.  You give a basket to one of the sisters and they leave home with instructions to follow the path to Grandma’s house.  The whole point of the game is not to do this, to wander through the forest where you interact with various items, collect flowers and objects.  As each sister meanders through the dense woodland, there are items and places specifically for her.  However, the player commences with no idea of what to look for, so there is a great emphasis on exploration.  In my opinion, much of the game is about unlocking the personalities of the sisters.  They are all different, although the stylisation and method through which we unravel this is systematic.

Each sister can meet her nemesis during her travels, but the guise of the wolf is different for every individual.  When these situations occur the player can only watch as the scenario unfolds.  After this event, the girl is transported to Grandma’s house and her journey through this domain depends upon what she has collected and encountered on her travels through the forest.  Here, each sister is upon a path pre-determined by her previous actions.

The Path can be described as a psychological game with a distinct horror edge, however I would argue there is more to the game than just this.  For instance, there is a definite attempt to blur the boundary between fine art and the video game.  One only has to watch the leafy tendrils growing around the games title as each sister begins her journey, to experience the surrealist arrangement of Grandma’s house and the cubist demise of each sister.  In addition, the music is haunting and the sound effects well judged.  One aspect of the game which I feel encompasses the horror element is what happens if the player causes a sister to run.  This is especially effective in a darkened room with the sound up.

The Path is a game to experience at your leisure.  It is a much slower paced game than any other I’ve encountered, but as the emphasis is on participating in each sister’s journey, the pacing works well – this isn’t a game to be rushed, its one to lose yourself in.

reviewText:
The Path is certainly a different gaming experience. A modern, gothic take on the classic Red Riding Hood Tale that articulates the dark cautionary elements quite well in subtle ways.

The game has but one objective: Go to grandmother's. Upon doing so, this means you've somehow lost the game, so as it turns out, you are actually encouraged to disobey the rules, and adventure into the dark, dreary forest, interacting with objects in the woods, skipping freely, getting completely lost. Eventually, you, as one of six 'Red' girls, will find what represents the Wolf, in one of it's various incarnations.
Upon meeting the wolf, you are taken back to the path, completely desolate and somber as you tread quietly to grandmother's in the rain. There, grandmother's house is no longer a sweet old lady's cottage but an absolute mind-♥♥♥♥ where you die, but you technically succeed in the game.

While the game is completely open to interpretation, and is more art-focused, this reward of defeat, especially after a character has been presumably injured, molested, or otherwise attacked, raises a few questions, considering rather than being able to outsmart the wolf, once you are locked into the animation, there is no way of fighting back. You essentially play 6 victims. Again, this is more of an artistic form of story telling, but it still raises a few questions.

Overall, visually, the game is appropriately sharp and goregous with a bit of an aesthetic to intice gamer-cult followings, and the soundtrack is fascinating and at times intensley dark. With so many themes and theories out there, this is a game for anyone who's looking for a different gaming experience, or for someone starting out in indie gaming. Or, simply for anyone into either gothic things or fairy tales.

reviewText:
The Path is centered around six sisters, each one a different Red Riding Hood that the player can take control of on the walk to their grandmother's house. Players are originally instructed to stay on the path on the way there. Upon reaching grandmother's house, players are treated with an eerily empty house, a mysterious rocking chair, and a pale old woman in bed with a stuffed wolf lingering nearby. Or, should they stray off the path, they encounter objects that inspire their chosen character to relive unpleasant memories. Gather enough of these memories and your character will encounter the dreaded wolf.

Unfortunately, what could have been an intriguing exploration game with a unique underlying concept is rendered more trouble than its worth by poorly designed gameplay. Each character you play as seems to move slower than the last, causing the game to suffer from terribly boring stretches of walking that seem to be taking you no where. The forest has very few noticeable landmarks or interesting sites to discover. I often found myself walking for long stretches of time, encountering absolutely nothing of interest. On top of the drearily slow pacing, the moment you start to feel like you're moving a little bit faster the camera swings to an inhospitable angle.

Overall, the Path has a pleasantly creepy vibe to it. The music is often discordant and mixed with child-like singing and chanting. The air is foggy and the forest is dark. The hallways of the grandmother's house are large and imposing and there's a sense of foreboding whether you stay on the path or adventure off of it. The memories you find are unnerving and just a little bit haunting. In terms of atmosphere, the Path is a clear winner. However, the poor controls make even turning your character clumsy and awkward. The game quickly becomes so tedious that it loses what charm it originally had going for it.

There's something to be said for the relaxation that comes with a good walking simulator. Many people debate over whether or not these type of artistic experiences" qualify as true video games

reviewText:
As it seems in the video game world, games heavily carried not by it's gameplay but by it's story and experience seem to be on the rise.

The Path is one of these games.

Extremely simple controls, as all you're given the option is to walk. In order to interact, you release the forward key. Gamers who are easily put off by a slow-pace, lack of action, and/or lower end graphics, I suggest you stop reading now, and shop elsewhere on Steam. However if you're a fan of exploration, experimentation, and a psychological approach on the horror genre, then by all means, keep reading.

This is in fact a horror game, despite the lack of actual jump scares or a monster chasing you. The Path is unique that instead- you're chasing the monster. Play one of the six sisters who is tasked to bring your sick grandmather some wine and bread, but by all means, don't stray off the path- or so, as the game warns you. Despite the game's warning, you won't be rewarded unless you go on the path less travelled and go in search of the sister's wolf, unique to her. To avoid spoilers, I will break down the experience without actually delving into the story outside of;

There's little to no voice acting. There's limited reading as each sister makes a remark on each object you do come across, as well as meeting her wolf. This minilmalist approach helps you get into the mindset of the sister, and what personality drives her to her decisions. Once meeting the wolf and finally arriving to grandmother's house are you treated with discovering the consequences of growing up and a bookend to that sister's story. Much like a silent film noted and influenced with a mix of an independent arthouse and a creepy horror film, enough is left unsaid to allow the players attempt to connect the pieces together. This leads to deep discussions creating webs around the game of everyone's different but meaningful and personal experiences.

The Path is ultimately unique, memorable, and gorgeous in concept and haunting in it's hidden messages. This game is not for everyone, but for those who've fond memories of finding an old book to dust off to read of the dark fairy tales of once ago. This game is for those who can handle strong adult themes that can unrattle those sensitive to graphic truths of the real world. I bought this game the first year it came out, and even today I find myself going back to it. Well worth my money, and time, over and over again.

reviewText:
The Path, from the recently and unfortunately departed Tale Of Tales, is a peculiar and perhaps polarizing experience that relies less on traditional gameplay functions and more on the player's curiosity and willingness to deviate from instruction. A unique take on the Red Riding Hood tale, you choose one of several young girls and are instructed to head to your grandmother's house without deviating from the established path in the forest. However, such things are never so simple.

If you like, you're welcome to obey the rules and keep to the safety of the titular Path. That's not where anything interesting happens, however. By diverting into the woods, each girl has a chance of finding a series of reminders that illuminate their past, some of which are more traumatic than others. As there are several Red Riding Hoods, so are there multiple Big Bad Wolves, all of whom intervene in a given Red's life in their own unique ways. By the way, let me add a trigger warning for what I think was an implied sexual assault in one of the stories.

The forest, its few inhabitants, the relics there, and the experiences following your discoveries upon your eventual arrival at grandma's are all beautifully rendered, and accompanied by a haunting, if limited in variety, soundtrack. The Path's decision to eschew dialogue for visual cues and symbolism helps get your imagination going, but at the same time makes certain sections more unclear than they ought to be. Even though the game quickly grew on me, even I had a few bouts of frustration between getting lost or being unsure what to do at certain points. Still, I enjoyed all the room left for interpretation with all the scenarios, and am still on the fence as to whether all the Reds are their own entities, if they're aspects of the same person (as they spread across a range of ages), or if they're something else entirely.

The Path is definitely a game with rather niche appeal, but if you're willing to let yourself get lost in a world for a bit, several times over, I'd say it's worth a look.

reviewText:
Something of a sophomore effort. Some of the art on the screen, the music (to some extent), and the concept are, well, nice. But the character models and the pacing leave quite a bit to be desired. The slooooow pace through the forest is the result of 1) an effort to comb through it looking for relevant objects/memory cues, 2) the rather random appearance of a map, which would be much more helpful for combing the forest more effectively, and 3) the bumpy walk/run mechanic, where you suddenly hit an invisible edge (of pools or memory glades) and have to maneuvre around. Unlike a game like _Gone Home_, I feel like this game is slow not because I want to stop and absorb the atmosphere or detail, but because the game is holding me back. Often it leaves me wondering what I should do - do I hit a button? Am I at the edge of the map, and should turn around?

In the end, I'm not sure what to do with this game. Is it a fairy story? Maybe. But too slow to use in the classroom: I'd feel bad asking someone to have to play this. It has a good heart, but not very useful.

4/10

reviewText:
What this game does well:
It has an artistic, non-concrete story that is somewhat creepy.  It is an interesting jumble of snippets from semi-related events.  The story, to me, felt more like seeing the shadow of an event, and being unsure what it really was.  What does it mean?  I believe this obscure feeling is quite intended, and is the main drive of playing the game.

What this game fails at (miserably):
Being a game.  The game doesn't just make you walk slowly around.  It makes you walk SLOWLY around.  Too slow!

It would be different if the graphics and music were a cool experience.  But they just aren't.  It's rather ugly.  The best part of the graphics are the scrawls and doodles that pop up on the screen, kind of like after seeing a bright light for a second.  But the trees, the characters, the ground... they all just look terrible.  If the game is working so hard to be artistic, they really need to consider the visual and auditory effect they are getting across.  Although, I understand that art can be whatever it wants to be... but I don't believe they were capable of improving the visuals.  If they were producing photorealistic scenery in other games, and then they decided to shoot specifically for this ugly style, then I'd say they made a bad choice, but accept their choice.  However, ToT has basically proven that they are not visual artists in the realm of 3D graphics.  Perhaps a case could be made for the color choices being well done, but it feels like such a small victory when one girl's buttcrack is a line awkwardly drawn on the back of her character.......

The sound was closer to getting across an effect, but I think they just didn't know how to get the effect across quite right.

One reviewer said of this game (paraphrase): The Path is not a game, it is art.

This is not entirely untrue.  It was a fun game that came bundled with something else.  I played through it, and although I enjoyed it, its not a game I would have bought for myself. If you're familiar with LRRH or CiTR - and if you are okay with a game with SLOW progression and a subjective scoring method... and if you're the kind of person that can fill in the gaps and analyze into a story - this game is for you.

I loved The Path.
It has everything I like in a game; deep atmosphere, creative storytelling, interesting characters, and it even appeals to the completionist in me.

It's definately not for everyone. If you're like me, the soundtrack and beautiful visual style will draw you right into the soft-horror atmosphere and will leave you torn between wanting to see everything the game has to offer and not wantnig to endanger the characters you come to care about. However, all of the storytelling is done through exploration and some players with worse luck may go a while before encountering anything that triggers an event or character moment (the endless trees can get a bit samey).

It's an art game; if you like those, there are few I've liked better.

reviewText:
Slow and boring.

Everything is slower than it should be. This starts when the game first begins and you watch an unskippable 30 second opening sequence (repeated every time you restart). After that it's similar to The Stanly Parable (tells you to do something while implying something else) except the world is huge and devoid of content. It took me 10 minutes to find the first memory and 30 more minutes to find the wolf. In between, you literally run through a forest for most of the game.

But even for a game about running through a forest it lacks. The controls are clunky. You can't look around using your mouse, the longer you sprint the worse your view gets, speed is painfully slow and turning is a nightmare. At certain points the camera angle changes and you become even worse off.

But then there's the story. It sucks. Each girl (this isn't told to you while playing) requires you to find a collection of memories and a wolf. The wolf represents a situation where the girl fell to temptation and lost their innocense. Memories and hidden rooms help you peice together how it happened. Its not obvious how you interact with some things (I've left wolves mid-sequence because I didn't know I was supposed to wait), and the stories are simple and boring (see tale of tales wiki to read them and save some time).

reviewText:
The Path is a dark and mature stroll through the equally dark forest, and does a great job of making you feel like the young characters, stumbling across new things and wanting to see what they are, woefully ignorant of the dangers nearby.

There are veins of hidden and underrated gems on Steam, and this one falls into the Unique & Interesting or Witty Obscure Indie Game that failed to gain popularity primarily because of its unique nature and lack of traditional gameplay elements. Which is a shame, because they, and this, are often priced very well and are short and unique enough to give a few hours of thought and fun.

Highlights
* Not over marketed - It isn't a traditional horror game like Amnesia, and hasn't been marketed as such, bravo Tale of Tales
* Really good sound and music design - an off-note girls choir is subtly haunting

Mistakes
* The graphics are jagged and low-res, which has been adjusted for with the art style, but better graphics and resolution would have helped bring out more in this title
* Invisible walls interrupt the immersion

Recommendations
Priced at £6.99/9.99€/$9.99 at the time of review. While undoubtedly cheap, the mere 3-5 hour play time makes it less valuable in terms of traditional playtime. At less than a buck on sale, it's most definitely worth checking out at -50% or less.

* The Path is better to play the less you know about it
* You can play a demo and pick up translation files for The Path on A Tale of Tales website[www.tale-of-tales.com]

reviewText:
Highly recommended.

The Path tells the tale of Little Red Riding Hood, at various different ages. It is a coming of age story about women, and has underlying themes that are sexual and violent.

A fable like Little Red Riding Hood seems straightforward, which is one reason we keep telling it. But why keep telling a simplistic story over and over again unless it has some meaning? The meaning, and other reason we still tell it, is that Little Red Riding Hood highlights the dangers of a girl's coming of age.

People complain the Path can be completed by just walking forward. The game allows you to reach an end stage that way, if you want it to be that straightforward. But you can also spend more time learning about the story and the different little Red Riding Hoods (or stages of her life) if you want.  The freedom to finish the game on your own time is a good gameplay mechanic.

This was one of the first digital games I bought (not on Steam, initially), and so it also gets props for that.

reviewText:
Right off the bat, I’ll say you as the player will either love this atmospheric exploration game or it’ll really wear on your patience fast. It can be mind-numbingly slow, confusing, and the controls are tolerable at best. There is almost no gameplay beyond exploration and collecting to speak of. Still I do recommend this game very highly to exploration lovers, role-players, and players with active imaginations. For these players I promise this game will have a lot of the things they enjoy in gaming.

Honestly, while I do highly recommend this game as stated above for open-minded players and exploration lovers. Personally, I found this game initially to be rather boring and hard to get into. As I tend to play more direct story driven and action oriented games. Yet, I decided to give The Path the play time I needed to honestly judge it. Out of sheer determination fueled by the other good reviews. Which generally said the game would get better if given time. For which was true in my case. I slowly started to get into this game as my predetermined notions of what makes good gameplay faded with each step I took into the dark woods. I quickly realized this game almost requires at least an hour or two to really judge it. Due to the game’s slow placing and subtle influences.

None of the game’s story line is directly force upon the player and is instead left to them to find and figure-out. While, initial gameplay as stated above may leave the gamer lost and confused. Once they do discover their story oriented purpose in game, either through sheer luck or logical deduction. Story-driven events will start to playout more often for them and the story should start to become clearer in their mind. Leading to the player’s enjoyment level most likely increasing or at least I believe so. As in my case, once I got that ah-ha! moment I started enjoying myself.

I have on purpose been rather vague with the details for those who do not like spoiler reviews so far. But for those who would like more to go off of. When deciding whether to give this interesting game a go or would like to just know more of what’s really going on in it. The follow two sections go into more descriptive detail. The first covers the gameplay elements and “generically” describes the goal of the game. The second further down one describes the games goal in-depth and does contains some direct story spoilers. Each section is tag with a warning label for those who rather avoid spoilers. If you choose to read on or not thank you very much for taking the time to read my review. - Olyth

--- WARNING: Gameplay related spoilers below ---



This game is ulitmately very dark and twisted. From the start you’re given two important choices to make. One which is obvious: Which of the young ladies would you like to play? The other, which is subtly hinted at: Is your chosen maiden going to be a good girl by following the given directions to head straight to her grandmother’s house without deviation or is she going to venture off the beaten path and explore the dark woods?

So logic would dictate initially you of course would obediently follow the directions you’re given and go straight to grandma’s house without deviation, right? Oh, how obedience in this game is so overrated. All you’ll get for your goody-two-shoes effort is a whopping “D” rating as your character arrives to sit at the bedside of her dead-looking grandmother. While the words “FAILURE” is plastered across your screen. Before the game unceremoniously plops you back on the character selection screen. Yep, the game wants your little Miss to be a disobedient minor. If you hope to receive anything above a “D” rank and some acknowledged “SUCCESS!”

Now if you’re girl does like to venture on the wild side and decides a little trip in the woods would be fun. Things are going to get a tad dark and atmospheric. As the game’s bright and cheery visuals turn quickly into a dark and eerie wooded locale with some lite horror elements introduced to set the mood. Also, to make things more interesting within mere seconds of leaving the path you’ll be completely lost and finding yourself walking in circles. Sounds like fun right? Well yes and somewhat no.

Wondering the woods lost is basically the initial core of the gameplay. As the girl explores she’ll come across random items and some limited interactions with other characters. Which is intended to give the player hints and imagery to build upon to develop their own personalize interpretation of the game’s story. Which not surprising will make the initial experience very confusing. Borderline leading to some to rage quit out of frustration and boredom.  As they will be most likely waiting for the game to give them a purpose or at least a goal to work towards. Something the player may gain either within a few minutes or may take upwards of an hour or two to figure out. If they stick around long enough. Depending on a little luck and a lot of patience.

After the player finishes his or her first character’s playthrough in the woods, either by coming across a key event or staying lost and running out of time. The goal of the game kind of becomes clear to the player to a certain point. Which is to lead each girl one-by-one to their horrible demise. For which the player receives higher ratings depending on how many items they found and if they located the girl’s personal key event. I did say the game was dark and twisted.

--- WARNING: Contains story related spoilers ---




As I mention above the player is rated on whether the player choices to collect items and if they find the girl’s personal key event. By Now I sure you've most likely figure out from the game visuals and the fact that the girrls all wear red. This game is based off the Red Riding Hood Fable. So the key event the player is ultimately looking for to get the best rating is to locate the other main character in the red-riding hood story besides Red and Grandma. The big bad wolf who wants to eat the young maiden. Pretty obvious huh, if you think about it. Yep, what you’re now thinking is correct: the player’s ultimate goal to get the best rating is to systematically hunt down the wolf and sacrifice their poor character to him. With each girl’s experience in the process being unique and the wolf being a little different for each of them. Due to girls being of different ages and having their own personalized perspective of the events as they encounter them.

As the player finds girl’s personalize beast, they get to watch some unique cut-scenes of Red's and the wolf's initial encounter. Some being more entertaining than others. Before being taken to just outside their grandma’s house and allowed to enter it. Although, this visit is not as visually cheery as the good girl’s visit. Each girl gets their own twisted nightmarish version of the house to briefly tour. Before the player is shown the girl’s fate in the form of multiple image stills depicting their gruesome death by the big teeth and claws of their wolf. Followed by the player receiving a chapter completion prompt with that “SUCCESS!” they were looking for and an overall ranking as describe above.

Afterwards, the player is returned to the character screen to select their next victim. With the deceased girls no longer being present alluding to the horrors that befell them. Now what happens, when only a few girls are left or better yet; none…..? Is there something sinister going on behind the scenes. Maybe something to do with the memories and visions the girls saw. Well I going to leave that’s for the player to figure out; enjoy! Thanks again for reading my review/overview.

reviewText:
A work of art is a work of art, and it's difficult to critique it. Ultimately a critique will have more to do with whether you liked it/whether it resonated with you/how it affected you, and that's not a review, that's a response.

On the other hand, a work of interactive fiction has some responsibilities that have nothing to do with its message. The Path has terrible, confusing controls. Some of the controls sometimes work and sometimes don't. Most places you walk by holding down W/up arrow/forward, but in one place you have to tap it repeatedly instead. You spend way too much time being forced to walk one ... mile ... an hour ... I understand drama, but the basic walk speed should have been about double what it is. The times you have to walk the last stretch to Grandma's house are agonizingly slow.

There's supposed to be an action button, but I generally was only able to interact with things by approaching them until a ghostly closeup appeared in the window, then taking my hand off the controls. Having actions happen when controls aren't being manipulated is TERRIBLE interface design.

And then there are the location indicators along the outside of the screen. Given that most of the forest is empty, this is your primary means of locating the things you're looking for. But it doesn't respond quickly, it's hard to judge distances, and the map only pops up occasionally (!)

I'm not going to even attempt to talk about The Path's artistic merits. But even if this were the world's most beautiful painting, you'd still be looking at it through a broken, filthy window from 300 feet away. The weakness of the interface makes the basic act of playing through the work tedious and unpleasant.

I'd include a trigger warning for sexual violence imagery, but ... it's a freakin' Little Red Riding Hood game. Saying there's ♥♥♥♥ imagery in an adaptation of Little Red Riding Hood is like saying there's dairy in a glass of whole milk.
